author: Thomas Drake
title: DubT contract-driven livestream NFT
description: How can we rapidly deploy NFT to support performing artists that fall outside of the mold of NFT graphic artist?

assessments.note: This could be an interesting use case, and if it worked would draw a lot of new users into the Cardano ecosystem.

The proposal is an excellent concept that is likely to grow with further adoption of NFT's as an avenue for performers/artists to commodify their talents. A good deal of work evident but lacks supporting documents.

I found this idea very interesting, different from the approach of most of the proposals I saw here. In general, many proposals seek to improve situations and practices that already exist, inside and outside the Cardano community, but this search brings to the context of the community something that is not usually included. The less traditional art forms to be associated with tokens and NFT, such as music presentations, from what I understand. Therefore, I believe that this project can bring a differential to the community, add value and even attract new members, producers of this content.

It took me two reads - from end to end - to get a full grasp of the idea and the proposal's depth. I like idea it seems both simple and complex at the same time and it does seem novel. The proposed DubToken & digital marketplace that re linked to livestream content - effectively expands the NFT paradigma to include many more types of artists - or even wider - broadcasters in fact. The integration with YouTube and Twitch offers many possibilities.  It might have been good to envisage a partnership even with famous non-artist Youtubers from the Cardano ecosystem that would help to popularize the concept - but that doesn't detract from the value of the idea. If successfully realized, this proposal would generate value for the Cardano ecosystem, while it also carves out a unique and underserved space for NFTs.

Reserving a part of the requested funds for the proposal for artists is an unfortunate move. It weakens the proposal. Funding artists are  not a good fit for Dapps & Integration challenge. The idea itself is interesting and worth exploring. The scope of the proposal is quite big. I would be easier to evaluate smaller proposals for the stated solutions (3). apart from the concerns expressed, the implementation of a distributed and fair compensation for live streams is a suitable proposal for the Challenge.

This is one of many proposals for NFT integration with the music industry.  Successful implementation of such a system would certainly have a beneficial effect on the Cardano ecosystem in terms of transactions and adoption. However, the competition will be fierce and many projects will ultimately fail due to a lack of technical expertise, industry connections, and/or network effect.

The proposal aims to monetize streaming media using the DubToken media service relay. This offers a methodology for establishing ownership of the streams.  The use of centralized servers is unavoidable in the present-day streaming solutions however the proposal adds one more relay, which might degrade the lag and jitter performance.

The audience for live streaming has grown substantially in the past years, so has the number of creatives and content creators involved. The Cardano ecosystem would probably benefit greatly from capturing and driving adoption of the blockchain in that audience. The idea is promising, however I would suggest refining the points I mention in my assessments bellow and resubmitting the proposal in a future fund.
It would be good to have more information to back-up the proposers claim to experience and connections (linkedin profiles)

The plan appears well researched but does not provide any further evidence to help build the proposal. No links to supporting interfaces or even mock ups of portal. This makes it difficult to accurately assess whether implementation would follow. Experience too is somewhat barebones although the use of tech jargon (and the idea itself) suggests skills are likely evident. I would encourage further engagement with PC community to formalise such aspects.

Unfortunately, in this part, I found the explanation of the proposal to be very superficial. The author claims to have many years of experience with software development, and also that I work for notable companies like Amazon and Apple. However, it would be interesting to demonstrate the example of some of his works. In addition, it would be beneficial to better share who the project team members would be. In fact, it is not very clear whether the author intends to develop the system alone or in a group. But in any case, I always think it is essential to include a graphic designer to build an intuitive and ergonomic platform.

This proposal is written in a way that demonstrates technical knowledgeability and it is a shame that the proposer hasn't included other specific and publicly available evidence of relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal. 
The proposal states that the lead has "21yrs of building functional, distributed software" at Amazon, Apple, while partners are leaders in music and content design. It seems as if it would have been easy to validate this experience by providing flesh on the bones, alas the proposer has not done so. As it stands, this experience needs to be taken at face value, which is a minus for me.
25000 of funding is portioned to support 4 artists during alpha phase, however there is scarce detail about the selection of these artists - I would argue that this is an equally important element for a contract-driven livestream NFT - as demand and success will also be linked to the profile /desirability of the included artists. I do not see a rationale has been provided for allocating USD25,000 of funding to the 4 selected artists - instead of USD2,500 to 10 artists or USD50,000 to two artists (for example). 
The specific use of the requested USD 80000 is also not provided in detail, but for a project of this scope - a breakdown of the budget and costs is needed in my view. 
I would have liked to see more word about the challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation of this specific project - not just latency, but also from the point of view of users and artists. The end users are likely to be non-technical (users and artists alike) and their user experience could be a make-or-break element.
A general timetable is provided, which is a plus, as is the level of technical detail and thought that has been provided.

There are multiple aspects mentioned that need to be addressed to provide the proposed solution. This will be a very complex challenge with aspects that are outside of conventional development for blockchain applications. For example the real-time aspect. The complexity and only very basic information about the relevant experience cause mit to go with neutral.

The proposer touts functional development work at Amazon and Apple and has partnered with musicians. Unfortunately no links are provided to verify the qualifications. No mention is made of smart contract experience or connections to the music industry.  While the proposal does detail specific stages and goals, there is little discussion of how these would be achieved on a technical level. 4 musicians also seems a small number to bootstrap such a project to a state of relevance.

Proposer claims 21 years of experience in distributed software building in Amazon, and partners have experience in the music industry.  However, references to past work and verifiable credentials are not enclosed in the proposal.

The proposed project seems a lot more complex than many, so a lot more details could have been provided to allow for a better assessment of its chances of success. The description of the proposers experience is very promising, but no credentials or links to previous works are given to allow the community to verify and better judge for themselves. The items on the roadmap lack a justification of given times and without one, some of them seem unfeasible, for instance why would "backend prototype & load testing" only take 2-3 weeks. A clear description of the team that would work on the project is not given, would it be just the proposers?
Without proof the proposers have connections in the music industry it is hard to asses the feasibility of this proposal.

Again, whilst I think this idea is a really useful potential I found it was very difficult to assess accurately. Budget seems valid but perhaps if author(s) had requested initial start up fund (V1) with the completion of same leading to request for further funds. The proposal needs to provide greater clarity of roadmap and skillset information to meet criteria.

The author of the proposal provides an action plan, in which he specifies what will be done, in what order, and how long each stage will last. In addition, it establishes what are the expectations of expected results and how the requested fund would be divided. Regarding the last point, I was a little in doubt about how much of the money would be destined for the actual construction of this project (which I also didn't understand if it would be an app or a website). The author says that USD 25000 would be earmarked for supported artists... but what do you mean? It would be beneficial to explain how support would be used, for example. Apart from that, I believe that the project is well planned and structured.

As it stands now, the proposal seems to be auditable because the roadmap has identifiable  deliverables and they are time-related. The success metrics do not include parameters about the quality of the proposed solution and the user-friendliness of the entire experience. I think that those parameters are key to successful adoption of a project like this that has many integrations and moving pieces. So, the fullness of this proposal cannot be measured solely on technical merit - it aslo includes that issue of whether it has covered all the bases - meaning that it will lead to success when built. 
I have not been convinced that supporting four artists with 25000 of funding is the right way to proceed - although it is part of the offered solution. Maybe more possible paths to adoption could have been explored in the solution. The proposed metrics seem to be relatively underwhelming. 
Diversity of  artists by end of alpha period does not seem to be an important factor in my view, as it is not a true measure of success - when 4 artists are involved. The limited beta is anyway out of the scope of the F5 proposal. The weekly active platform-integrated users - demonstrating broad adoption - is a metric, but what will represent succcess is not clear from the proposal. Also the number of monthly private-stream events will be a number that can be clocked, but what is success? A trend? A finite number? The proposer hasn't quantified success, so almost anything might qualify as success in a sense. 
Essentially, I would have liked to see a much better and detailed consideration of success for this proposal that is not purely technical in nature. It involves an artistic element, an audience and interaction.
There is no budget breakdown in the proposal. Only that 25000 USD are used to support 4 artists during alpha phase. There is a basic roadmap and not KPIs provided.

25k of funding is allocated to support artists during the testing stages.  It will be difficult to audit the impact of these funds.  the direction of the other 55k towards the V1 roadmap is not discussed in any detail.  This is probably due to a lack of understanding of the technical requirements for the project.

The proposal has clear objectives defined phase-wise and can be monitored for progress. The development steps have been provided with time limits.  The project's success can be measured based on the number of people adopting the solution and can be measured analytically.

I would suggest including a clear and explained breakdown of all costs in the requested budged. As this project requires a complex platform being built I would have liked to see a clearer description of the development work required and clearer task assignment, it's a larger project and it's unclear if the team would need to hire outside help. No mention of a launch date for the project is made, so it would be hard for the community to keep track of development. Metrics given are broad and they don't really apply to the V1 of the project, which is the scope of this proposal.

solution: DubToken allows streaming creators to both fund unique performances and mint stream-derived NFTs through a contract-directed media service.
experience: Lead has 21yrs of building functional, distributed software at Amazon, Apple. Partners are leaders in music and content design.
